lines.text: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV sick, QUEEN  ELIZABETH, DORSET, RIVERS, HASTINGS, BUCKINGHAM, GREY, and others

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Why, so: now have I done a good day's work: You peers, continue this united league: I every day expect an embassage From my Redeemer to redeem me hence; And now in peace my soul shall part to heaven, Since I have set my friends at peace on earth. Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand; Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.

lines.speaker: rivers
lines.text: By heaven, my heart is purged from grudging hate: And with my hand I seal my true heart's love.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: So thrive I, as I truly swear the like!

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Take heed you dally not before your king; Lest he that is the supreme King of kings Confound your hidden falsehood, and award Either of you to be the other's end.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love!

lines.speaker: rivers
lines.text: And I, as I love Hastings with my heart!

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Madam, yourself are not exempt in this, Nor your son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you; You have been factious one against the other, Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand; And what you do, do it unfeignedly.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: Here, Hastings; I will never more remember Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine!

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love lord marquess.

lines.speaker: dorset
lines.text: This interchange of love, I here protest, Upon my part shall be unviolable.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: And so swear I, my lord
They embrace

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife's allies, And make me happy in your unity.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate On you or yours, but with all duteous love Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me With hate in those where I expect most love! When I have most need to employ a friend, And most assured that he is a friend Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile, Be he unto me! this do I beg of God, When I am cold in zeal to yours.
To the Queen

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, is this thy vow unto my sickly heart. There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here, To make the perfect period of this peace.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: And, in good time, here comes the noble duke.
Enter GLOUCESTER

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen: And, princely peers, a happy time of day!

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Happy, indeed, as we have spent the day. Brother, we done deeds of charity; Made peace enmity, fair love of hate, Between these swelling wrong-incensed peers.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: A blessed labour, my most sovereign liege: Amongst this princely heap, if any here, By false intelligence, or wrong surmise, Hold me a foe; If I unwittingly, or in my rage, Have aught committed that is hardly borne By any in this presence, I desire To reconcile me to his friendly peace: 'Tis death to me to be at enmity; I hate it, and desire all good men's love. First, madam, I entreat true peace of you, Which I will purchase with my duteous service; Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham, If ever any grudge were lodged between us; Of you, Lord Rivers, and, Lord Grey, of you; That without desert have frown'd on me; Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed, of all. I do not know that Englishman alive With whom my soul is any jot at odds More than the infant that is born to-night I thank my God for my humility.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter: I would to God all strifes were well compounded. My sovereign liege, I do beseech your majesty To take our brother Clarence to your grace.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Why, madam, have I offer'd love for this To be so bouted in this royal presence? Who knows not that the noble duke is dead? You do him injury to scorn his corse.
They all start

lines.speaker: rivers
lines.text: Who knows not he is dead! who knows he is?

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: All seeing heaven, what a world is this!

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?

lines.speaker: dorset
lines.text: Ay, my good lord; and no one in this presence But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Is Clarence dead? the order was reversed.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: But he, poor soul, by your first order died, And that a winged Mercury did bear: Some tardy cripple bore the countermand, That came too lag to see him buried. God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion!
Enter DERBY

lines.speaker: dorset
lines.text: A boon, my sovereign, for my service done!

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: I pray thee, peace: my soul is full of sorrow.

lines.speaker: dorset
lines.text: I will not rise, unless your highness grant.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Then speak at once what is it thou demand'st.

lines.speaker: dorset
lines.text: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant's life; Who slew to-day a righteous gentleman Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Have a tongue to doom my brother's death, And shall the same give pardon to a slave? My brother slew no man; his fault was thought, And yet his punishment was cruel death. Who sued to me for him? who, in my rage, Kneel'd at my feet, and bade me be advised Who spake of brotherhood? who spake of love? Who told me how the poor soul did forsake The mighty Warwick, and did fight for me? Who told me, in the field by Tewksbury When Oxford had me down, he rescued me, And said, 'Dear brother, live, and be a king'? Who told me, when we both lay in the field Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me Even in his own garments, and gave himself, All thin and naked, to the numb cold night? All this from my remembrance brutish wrath Sinfully pluck'd, and not a man of you Had so much grace to put it in my mind. But when your carters or your waiting-vassals Have done a drunken slaughter, and defaced The precious image of our dear Redeemer, You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon; And I unjustly too, must grant it you But for my brother not a man would speak, Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself For him, poor soul. The proudest of you all Have been beholding to him in his life; Yet none of you would once plead for his life. O God, I fear thy justice will take hold On me, and you, and mine, and yours for this! Come, Hastings, help me to my closet. Oh, poor Clarence!
Exeunt some with KING EDWARD IV and QUEEN MARGARET

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: This is the fruit of rashness! Mark'd you not How that the guilty kindred of the queen Look'd pale when they did hear of Clarence' death? O, they did urge it still unto the king! God will revenge it. But come, let us in, To comfort Edward with our company.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: We wait upon your grace.
Exeunt
